Cabinet">Italian government</a> task force</li></ul>\n</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Disease</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">Coronavirus disease 2019</a> (COVID-19)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Virus strain</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2">Severe acute respiratory syndrome<br />coronavirus 2</a> (SARS\xe2\x80\x91CoV\xe2\x80\x912)<sup id="cite_ref-fn1_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fn1-1">&#91;a&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Source</th><td class="infobox-data">Likely via <a href="/wiki/Bat" title="Bat">bats</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Location</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory" title="COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory">Worldwide</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">First outbreak</th><td class="infobox-data">Wuhan, China<sup id="cite_ref-auto_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Index_case" title="Index case">Index case</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hubei" title="Hubei">Hubei</a>, China<br /><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=COVID-19_pandemic&amp;params=30_37_11_N_114_15_28_E_type:adm2nd_region:CN-42"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">30\xc2\xb037\xe2\x80\xb211\xe2\x80\xb3N</span> <span class="longitude">114\xc2\xb015\xe2\x80\xb228\xe2\x80\xb3E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#xfeff; / &#xfeff;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">30.61972\xc2\xb0N 114.25778\xc2\xb0E</span><span style="display:none">&#xfeff; / <span class="geo">30.61972; 114.25778</span></span></span></a></span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Date</th><td class="infobox-data">December&#160;2019<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">2019-12</span>)</span><sup id="cite_ref-auto_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> \xe2\x80\x93 present<br />(1&#160;year, 5&#160;months and 6&#160;days)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Confirmed cases</th><td class="infobox-data">155,475,984<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Suspected cases<sup>\xe2\x80\xa1</sup></th><td class="infobox-data">Possibly 10% of the global population, or 780 million people (WHO estimate as of early October 2020)<sup id="cite_ref-IyW9b_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IyW9b-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Deaths</div></th><td class="infobox-data">3,247,557<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="display:inline-block; padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Territories</div></th><td class="infobox-data">192<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-below" style="text-align:left; border-top:#aaa 1px solid;"><sup>\xe2\x80\xa1</sup><i>Suspected cases have not been confirmed by laboratory tests as being due to this strain, although some other strains may have been ruled out.</i></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The <b>COVID-19 pandemic</b>, also known as the <b>coronavirus pandemic</b>, is an ongoing <a href="/wiki/Pandemic#COVID-19" title="Pandemic">global pandemic</a> of <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">coronavirus disease 2019</a> (COVID-19) caused by <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2">severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2</a> (SARS-CoV-2). The <a href="/wiki/Virus" title="Virus">virus</a> was first identified in December 2019 in <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> declared a <a href="/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern" title="Public Health Emergency of International Concern">Public Health Emergency of International Concern</a> regarding COVID-19 on 30 January 2020, and later declared a <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">pandemic</a> on 11 March 2020. As of 6 May 2021, <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_cases" title="COVID-19 pandemic cases">more than 155<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million cases</a> have been confirmed, with <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_deaths" title="COVID-19 pandemic deaths">more than 3.24<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million deaths</a> attributed to COVID-19, making it one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_epidemics#Major_epidemics_and_pandemics_by_death_toll" title="List of epidemics">deadliest pandemics in history</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID-19" title="Symptoms of COVID-19">Symptoms of COVID-19</a> are highly variable, ranging from <a href="/wiki/Asymptomatic" title="Asymptomatic">none</a> to life-threateningly severe. <a href="/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19" title="Transmission of COVID-19">Transmission of COVID-19</a> occurs mainly when an infected person is in close contact<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup> with another person.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:23_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:23-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_droplet" title="Respiratory droplet">Small droplets</a> containing the virus leave an infected person as they breathe, cough, sneeze, or speak and enter another person via their mouth, nose, or eyes. <a href="/wiki/Airborne_transmission" title="Airborne transmission">Airborne transmission</a> is also sometimes possible, as smaller infected droplets can linger in the air for minutes to hours within enclosed spaces that have inadequate ventilation.<sup id="cite_ref-:23_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:23-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> Less commonly, the virus may spread via <a href="/wiki/Fomite" title="Fomite">contaminated surfaces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:23_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:23-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> People remain contagious for up to 20 days, and can spread the virus even if they do not develop any symptoms.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Recommended <a href="/wiki/Preventive_healthcare" title="Preventive healthcare">preventive measures</a> include <a href="/wiki/Social_distancing_measures_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic">social distancing</a>, wearing <a href="/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic">face masks</a> in public, ventilation and air-filtering, <a href="/wiki/Hand_washing" title="Hand washing">hand washing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_etiquette" class="mw-redirect" title="Respiratory etiquette">covering one\'s mouth when sneezing or coughing</a>, disinfecting surfaces, and monitoring and <a href="/wiki/Self-isolation" class="mw-redirect" title="Self-isolation">self-isolation</a> for people exposed or symptomatic. <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine" title="COVID-19 vaccine">Several vaccines</a> have been developed and widely distributed since December 2020. Current <a href="/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19" title="Treatment and management of COVID-19">treatments</a> focus on addressing symptoms, but work is underway to <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_drug_development" title="COVID-19 drug development">develop therapeutic drugs</a> that inhibit the virus. Authorities worldwide <a href="/wiki/National_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic">have responded</a> by implementing <a href="/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic">travel restrictions</a>, <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns" title="COVID-19 lockdowns">lockdowns/quarantines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Workplace_hazard_controls_for_COVID-19" title="Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19">workplace hazard controls</a>, and business closures. Many places have also worked to increase <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_testing" title="COVID-19 testing">testing</a> capacity and <a href="/wiki/Contact_tracing" title="Contact tracing">trace contacts</a> of the infected.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The pandemic has resulted in significant global <a href="/wiki/Social_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Social impact of the COVID-19 pandemic">social</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic">economic disruption</a>, including <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_recession" title="COVID-19 recession">the largest global recession</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RFXoH_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RFXoH-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> It has led to <a href="/wiki/Shortages_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic">widespread supply shortages</a> exacerbated by <a href="/wiki/Panic_buying" title="Panic buying">panic buying</a>, agricultural disruption and <a href="/wiki/Food_security_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Food security during the COVID-19 pandemic">food shortages</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_the_environment" title="Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the environment">decreased emissions of pollutants and greenhouse gases</a>. Numerous <a href="/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_education" title="Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on education">educational institutions</a> and public areas have been partially or fully closed, and many <a href="/wiki/List_of_events_affected_by_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="List of events affected by the COVID-19 pandemic">events have been cancelled or postponed</a>. <a href="/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic">Misinformation has circulated</a> through social media and mass media. The pandemic has raised issues of <a href="/wiki/Xenophobia_and_racism_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Xenophobia and racism related to the COVID-19 pandemic">racial and geographic discrimination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Health_equity" title="Health equity">health equity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Individual_and_group_rights" title="Individual and group rights">the balance</a> between public health imperatives and individual rights.\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48"><a href="#United_Nations_response_measures"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">United Nations response measures</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-49"><a href="#WHO_response_measures"><span class="tocnumber">6.3.1</span> <span class="toctext">WHO response measures</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50"><a href="#Protests_against_governmental_measures"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Protests against governmental measures</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-51"><a href="#Impact"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Impact</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-52"><a href="#Economics"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Economics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-53"><a href="#Supply_shortages"><span class="tocnumber">7.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Supply shortages</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-54"><a href="#Oil_and_other_energy_markets"><span class="tocnumber">7.1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Oil and other energy markets</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-55"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-56"><a href="#Politics"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Politics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-57"><a href="#China_2"><span class="tocnumber">7.3.1</span> <span class="toctext">China</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-58"><a href="#Italy_2"><span class="tocnumber">7.3.2</span> <span class="toclevel-3 tocsection-60"><a href="#Other_countries"><span class="tocnumber">7.3.4</span> <span class="toctext">Other countries</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-61"><a href="#Agriculture_and_food_systems"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Agriculture and food systems</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-62"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">7.5</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-63"><a href="#Other_health_issues"><span class="tocnumber">7.6</span> <span class="toctext">Other health issues</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-64"><a href="#Environment_and_climate"><span class="tocnumber">7.7</span> <span class="toctext">Environment and climate</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-65"><a href="#Xenophobia_and_racism"><span class="tocnumber">7.8</span> <span class="toctext">Xenophobia and racism</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-66"><a href="#Lifestyle_change_adaptation_during_the_pandemic"><span class="tocnumber">7.9</span> <span class="toctext">Lifestyle change adaptation during the pandemic</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-67"><a href="#Information_dissemination"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Information dissemination</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-68"><a href="#Misinformation"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Misinformation</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-69"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-70"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-71"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-72"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-73"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-74"><a href="#Health_agencies"><span class="tocnumber">13.1</span> <span class="toctext">Health agencies</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-75"><a href="#Directories"><span class="tocnumber">13.2</span> <span class="toctext">Directories</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-76"><a href="#Data_and_graphs"><span class="tocnumber">13.3</span> <span class="toctext">Data and graphs</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-77"><a href="#Medical_journals"><span class="tocnumber">13.4</span> <span class="toctext">Medical journals</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-78"><a href="#Research_foundations"><span class="tocnumber">13.5</span> <span class="toctext">Research foundations</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Epidemiology">Epidemiology</span></h2>\n<table class="infobox"><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-subheader">For country-level <a href="/wiki/Template:COVID-19_pandemic_data" title="Template:COVID-19 pandemic data">data</a>, see:</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-subheader"><div style="padding:3px 0"><big><big><b><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory" title="COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory">COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory</a></b></big></big></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-image"><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country" title="732-bar-chart"><img alt="732-bar-chart" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/732-bar-chart.svg/80px-732-bar-chart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="80" height="80" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/732-bar-chart.svg/120px-732-bar-chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/732-bar-chart.svg/160px-732-bar-chart.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="512" /></a><div class="infobox-caption"><div style="width:80%;margin:0 auto">\n  <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716"/><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 7em;">\n  <div><b><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_cases" title="COVID-19 pandemic cases">Cases</a></b><br /><span style="font-size:1.2em;">155,475,984</span></div>\n  <div><b><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_deaths" title="COVID-19 pandemic deaths">Deaths</a></b><br /><span style="font-size:1.2em;">3,247,557</span></div>\n  </div>\n </div>\n<div style="margin-top:10px">As of 6 May 2021<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></div></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-below"><div style="margin:5px 10px 5px;font-weight:bold;"><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Africa">Africa</a> \xc2\xb7 <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Asia" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Asia">Asia</a> \xc2\xb7 <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Europe" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Europe">Europe</a> \xc2\xb7 <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_North_America" title="COVID-19 pandemic in North America">North America</a> <br /> <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Oceania" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Oceania">Oceania</a> \xc2\xb7 <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America" title="COVID-19 pandemic in South America">South America</a></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Investigations_into_the_origin_of_COVID-19" title="Investigations into the origin of COVID-19">Investigations into the origin of COVID-19</a></div>\n<p>Although the exact origin of the virus is still unknown, the first <a href="/wiki/Outbreak" class="mw-redirect" title="Outbreak">outbreak</a> started in <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hubei" title="Hubei">Hubei</a>, China in late 2019. Many early cases of COVID-19 were linked to people who had visited the <a href="/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market" title="Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market">Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market</a> in Wuhan,<sup id="cite_ref-41UYw_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41UYw-16">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:5_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> but it is possible that human-to-human transmission was already happening before this.<sup id="cite_ref-Hu2020natureReviews_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Graham2020immunity_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-20">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> On 11 February 2020, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) named the disease "COVID-19", which is short for <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" class="mw-redirect" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">coronavirus disease 2019</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TLY19_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TLY19-21">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cD8mY_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cD8mY-22">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The virus that caused the outbreak is known as <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2">severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2</a> (SARS-CoV-2), a newly discovered virus closely related to <a href="/wiki/Bat_virome#Coronaviruses" title="Bat virome">bat coronaviruses</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-LancetNowcasting_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LancetNowcasting-23">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pangolin" title="Pangolin">pangolin</a> coronaviruses,<sup id="cite_ref-ia56U_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ia56U-24">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Zhang6April2020_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zhang6April2020-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus">SARS-CoV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ECDC_risk_assessment_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECDC_risk_assessment-26">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Scientific consensus is that COVID-19 is a <a href="/wiki/Zoonosis" title="Zoonosis">zoonotic</a> virus that arose from <a href="/wiki/Bat" title="Bat">bats</a> in a natural setting,<sup id="cite_ref-EA-20200317_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EA-20200317-27">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NM-20200317_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NM-20200317-28">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> although the exact original host and cross-species infection routes remain in need of further investigation.<sup id="cite_ref-Hu2020natureReviews_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-19">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Despite this, the subject has generated a significant amount of online conspiracy theories.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Graham2020immunity_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-20">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The earliest known person with symptoms was later discovered to have fallen ill on 1<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>December 2019, and that person did not have visible connections with the later <a href="/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market#Link_to_COVID-19" title="Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market">wet market</a> cluster.<sup id="cite_ref-AutoDW-67_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AutoDW-67-31">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wang24Jan2020_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wang24Jan2020-32">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> However, an earlier case of infection could have occurred on 17 November.<sup id="cite_ref-November_case_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-November_case-33">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> Of the early cluster of cases reported that month, two thirds were found to have a link with the market.<sup id="cite_ref-Huang24Jan2020_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-34">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Joseph24Jan2020_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joseph24Jan2020-35">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-han24Jan2020_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-han24Jan2020-36">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> There are several theories about when and where the very first case (the so-called <a href="/wiki/Index_case" title="Index case">patient zero</a>) originated.<sup id="cite_ref-patientZero_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patientZero-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cases">Cases</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory" title="COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory">COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory</a> and <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_cases" title="COVID-19 pandemic cases">COVID-19 pandemic cases</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg/350px-COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg/525px-COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg/700px-COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2921" data-file-height="1500" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_Outbreak_World_Map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Total confirmed cases per country as of 27 April 2021. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716"/><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 12em;column-gap: 0;padding-left:3em;"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#290000; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;10,000,000+</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#510000; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;1,000,000\xe2\x80\x939,999,999</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#900000; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;100,000\xe2\x80\x93999,999</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#c80200; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;10,000\xe2\x80\x9399,999</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ee7070; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;1,000\xe2\x80\x939,999</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ffc0c0; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;100\xe2\x80\x93999</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ffdfe0; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;1\xe2\x80\x9399</div></li><li style="margin: 0;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#e0e0e0; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;0</div></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div>\n<p>Official case counts refer to the number of people who have been <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_testing" title="COVID-19 testing">tested for COVID-19</a> and whose test has been confirmed positive according to official protocols.<sup id="cite_ref-1ceLG_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1ceLG-38">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-J0rix_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J0rix-39">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> Many countries, early on, had official policies to not test those with only mild symptoms.<sup id="cite_ref-elpais640000_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elpais640000-40">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20200313reuters_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20200313reuters-41">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> An analysis of the early phase of the outbreak up to 23 January estimated 86 percent of COVID-19 infections had not been detected, and that these undocumented infections were the source for 79 percent of documented cases.<sup id="cite_ref-Li_eabb3221_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Li_eabb3221-42">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Several other studies, using a variety of methods, have estimated that numbers of infections in many countries are likely to be considerably greater than the reported cases.<sup id="cite_ref-WqXOo_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WqXOo-43">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BtFLV_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BtFLV-44">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 9 April 2020, <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_Case-Cluster-Study" title="COVID-19 Case-Cluster-Study">preliminary results</a> found that 15 percent of people tested in <a href="/wiki/Gangelt" title="Gangelt">Gangelt</a>, the centre of a major infection cluster in Germany, tested positive for <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">antibodies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-otW1O_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-otW1O-45">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> Screening for COVID-19 in pregnant women in New York City, and <a href="/wiki/Blood_donor" class="mw-redirect" title="Blood donor">blood donors</a> in the Netherlands, has also found rates of positive antibody tests that may indicate more infections than reported.<sup id="cite_ref-rCdvL_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rCdvL-46">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20200416reuters_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20200416reuters-47">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> Seroprevalence based estimates are conservative as some studies show that persons with mild symptoms do not have detectable antibodies.<sup id="cite_ref-0LgFK_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-0LgFK-48">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Some results (such as the Gangelt study) have received substantial press coverage without first passing through peer review.<sup id="cite_ref-dSUxs_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dSUxs-49">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>An analysis in early 2020 of cases by age in China indicated that a relatively low proportion of cases occurred in individuals under 20.<sup id="cite_ref-statista1095024_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statista1095024-50">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> It was not clear whether this was because young people were less likely to be infected, or less likely to develop serious symptoms and seek medical attention and be tested.<sup id="cite_ref-vox21190033_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vox21190033-51">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> A retrospective <a href="/wiki/Cohort_study" title="Cohort study">cohort study</a> in China found that <a href="/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_children" title="Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on children">children</a> and adults were just as likely to be infected.<sup id="cite_ref-489Q3_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489Q3-52">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Initial estimates of the <a href="/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number" title="Basic reproduction number">basic reproduction number</a> (R<sub>0</sub>) for COVID-19 in January were between 1.4 and 2.5,<sup id="cite_ref-WFNfK_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WFNfK-53">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> but a subsequent analysis concluded that it may be about 5.7 (with a 95 percent <a href="/wiki/Confidence_interval" title="Confidence interval">confidence interval</a> of 3.8 to 8.9).<sup id="cite_ref-mmCQc_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmCQc-54">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> R<sub>0</sub> can vary across populations and is not to be confused with the <a href="/wiki/Effective_reproduction_number" class="mw-redirect" title="Effective reproduction number">effective reproduction number</a> (commonly just called R), which takes into account effects such as social distancing and <a href="/wiki/Herd_immunity" title="Herd immunity">herd immunity</a>. By mid-May 2020, the effective R was close to or below 1.0 in many countries, meaning the spread of the disease in these areas at that time was stable or decreasing.<sup id="cite_ref-20200508telegraph_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20200508telegraph-55">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 422.66666666667px"><div style="width: 422.66666666667px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 420.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png/631px-Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png" decoding="async" width="421" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png/947px-Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/Covid-19_new_cases_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png 2x" data-file-width="1042" data-file-height="545" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>Semi-log plot of weekly new cases of COVID-19 in the world and top five current countries (mean with deaths)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 310px"><div style="width: 310px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 308px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png/462px-Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png" decoding="async" width="308" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png/693px-Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/83/Covid-19_total_cases_per_100_000_population_from_selected_countries.png 2x" data-file-width="791" data-file-height="565" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>COVID-19 total cases per 100 000 population from selected countries<sup id="cite_ref-ECDC_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECDC-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 310px"><div style="width: 310px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 308px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png/462px-COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png" decoding="async" width="308" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png/693px-COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1d/COVID-19_Active_Cases_per_100_000_population.png 2x" data-file-width="791" data-file-height="565" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>COVID-19 active cases per 100 000 population from selected countries<sup id="cite_ref-ECDC_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECDC-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n</ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Deaths">Deaths</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_deaths" title="COVID-19 pandemic deaths">COVID-19 pandemic deaths</a> and <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_death_rates_by_country" title="COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country">COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_deaths_due_to_COVID-19" title="List of deaths due to COVID-19">List of deaths due to COVID-19</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg/220px-COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg/330px-COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg/440px-COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2250" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID19_deceased_in_Hackensack_NJ_April_27.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Deceased in a 16&#160;m (53&#160;ft) "mobile morgue" outside a hospital in <a href="/wiki/Hackensack,_New_Jersey" title="Hackensack, New Jersey">Hackensack, New Jersey</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Official deaths from COVID-19 generally refer to people who died after testing positive according to protocols. These counts may ignore deaths of people who die without having been tested.<sup id="cite_ref-20200331reuters_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20200331reuters-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Conversely, deaths of people who had underlying conditions may lead to over-counting.<sup id="cite_ref-stuff120443722_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stuff120443722-58">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> Comparisons of statistics for deaths for all causes versus the seasonal average indicate excess mortality in many countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Wu_2020_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wu_2020-59">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gR8g3_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gR8g3-60">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> This may include deaths due to strained healthcare systems and bans on <a href="/wiki/Elective_surgery" title="Elective surgery">elective surgery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20200429reason_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20200429reason-61">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> The first confirmed death was in Wuhan on 9 January 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-AutoDW-25_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AutoDW-25-62">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> The first reported death outside of China occurred on<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>1 February in the Philippines,<sup id="cite_ref-NYT2020PhilDeath_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT2020PhilDeath-63">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> and the first reported death outside Asia was in the United States on 6 February.<sup id="cite_ref-FpBPA_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FpBPA-64">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>More than 95 percent of the people who contract COVID-19 recover. Otherwise, the time between symptoms onset and death usually ranges from<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>6 to 41 days, typically about 14 days.<sup id="cite_ref-pathogenesis_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pathogenesis-65">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> As of 6 May 2021, more than 3.24<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>million<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> deaths have been attributed to COVID-19. People at the greatest risk of mortality from COVID-19 tend to be those with underlying conditions, such as those with a <a href="/wiki/Immunodeficiency" title="Immunodeficiency">weakened immune system</a>, serious heart or lung problems, severe <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, or the elderly (including individuals age 65 years or older).<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6XONR_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6XONR-67">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Multiple measures are used to quantify mortality.<sup id="cite_ref-wBm2a_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wBm2a-68">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> These numbers vary by region and over time, influenced by testing volume, healthcare system quality, treatment options, government response,<sup id="cite_ref-Xq94d_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Xq94d-69">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zxmXG_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zxmXG-70">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-o8Wjx_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-o8Wjx-71">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> time since the initial outbreak, and population characteristics, such as age, sex, and overall health.<sup id="cite_ref-worldindata_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldindata-72">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> Countries like Belgium include deaths from suspected cases of COVID-19, regardless of whether the person was tested, resulting in higher numbers compared to countries that include only test-confirmed cases.<sup id="cite_ref-npr841005901_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr841005901-73">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths attributed to COVID-19 divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval. Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is <span data-sort-value="7000208878369279206\xe2\x99\xa0" style="display:none"></span>2.1&#160;percent (3,247,557 deaths for 155,475,984 cases) as of 6 May 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-JHU_ticker_4-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JHU_ticker-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> The number varies by region.<sup id="cite_ref-b0L7I_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b0L7I-74">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 503.33333333333px"><div style="width: 503.33333333333px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 501.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Covid-19_daily_deaths_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Covid-19_daily_deaths_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png/752px-Covid-19_daily_deaths_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png" decoding="async" width="502" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/36/Covid-19_daily_deaths_in_top_5_countries_and_the_world.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1011" data-file-height="444" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>Semi-log plot of weekly deaths due to COVID-19 in the world and top five current countries (mean with cases)\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n\t\t<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 310px"><div style="width: 310px">\n\t\t\t<div class="thumb" style="width: 308px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_deaths_per_100,000_population.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/COVID-19_deaths_per_100%2C000_population.png/462px-COVID-19_deaths_per_100%2C000_population.png" decoding="async" width="308" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/COVID-19_deaths_per_100%2C000_population.png/693px-COVID-19_deaths_per_100%2C000_population.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3d/COVID-19_deaths_per_100%2C000_population.png 2x" data-file-width="791" data-file-height="565" /></a></div></div>\n\t\t\t<div class="gallerytext">\n<p>COVID-19 deaths per 100 000 population from selected countries<sup id="cite_ref-ECDC_56-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECDC-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div></li>\n</ul>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Reporting">Reporting</span></h4>\n<p>On 24 March 2020, the <a href="/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention" title="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC) of the United States, indicated the WHO had provided two codes for COVID-19: U07.1 when confirmed by laboratory testing and U07.2 for clinically or epidemiological diagnosis where laboratory confirmation is inconclusive or not available.<sup id="cite_ref-MsVEW_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MsVEW-75">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> The CDC noted that "Because laboratory test results are not typically reported on death certificates in the U.S., [the <a href="/wiki/National_Center_for_Health_Statistics" title="National Center for Health Statistics">National Center for Health Statistics</a> (NCHS)] is not planning to implement U07.2 for mortality statistics" and that U07.1 would be used "If the death certificate reports terms such as \'probable COVID-19\' or \'likely COVID-19\'." The CDC also noted "It Is not likely that NCHS will follow up on these cases" and while the "underlying cause depends upon what and where conditions are reported on the death certificate, ... the rules for coding and selection of the ... cause of death are expected to result in COVID\xe2\x80\x9319 being the underlying cause more often than not."<sup id="cite_ref-MsVEW_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MsVEW-75">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 16 April 2020, the WHO, in its formal publication of the two codes, U07.1 and U07.2, "recognized that in many countries detail as to the laboratory confirmation... will not be reported [and] recommended, for mortality purposes only, to code COVID-19 provisionally to code U07.1 unless it is stated as \'probable\' or \'suspected\'."<sup id="cite_ref-d3wei_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d3wei-77">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5aSHW_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5aSHW-78">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> It was also noted that the WHO "does not distinguish" between infection by SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19.<sup id="cite_ref-Hauser_2020_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hauser_2020-79">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span id="Infection_fatality_ratio_.28IFR.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Infection_fatality_ratio_(IFR)">Infection fatality ratio (IFR)</span></h4>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1013635363">.mw-parser-output class="sidebar-title" style="background:"><a href="/wiki/Coronavirus" title="Coronavirus">Coronavirus</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a href="/wiki/File:Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg" class="image" title="HCoV-229E virus"><img alt="HCoV-229E virus" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg/160px-Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg/240px-Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg/320px-Coronaviruses_004_lores.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1368" /></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background:"><a href="/wiki/Coronavirus#Classification" title="Coronavirus">Types</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Alphacoronavirus" title="Alphacoronavirus">Alphacoronavirus</a></li>\n<li><a mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background:"><a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_diseases" title="Coronavirus diseases">Diseases</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Common_cold" title="Common cold">Common cold</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background:">Vaccines</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine" title="COVID-19 vaccine">COVID-19 vaccine</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background:">Epidemics and pandemics</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2002%E2%80%932004_SARS_outbreak" title="2002\xe2\x80\x932004 SARS outbreak">SARS</a> <small>(2002\xe2\x80\x932004)</small></li>\n<li>MERS\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2012_Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_outbreak" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus outbreak">2012</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/2015_Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome_outbreak_in_South_Korea" title="2015 Middle East respiratory syndrome outbreak in South Korea">2015</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/2018_Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome_outbreak" title="2018 Middle East respiratory syndrome outbreak">2018</a></li></ul></li>\n<li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">COVID-19</a> <small>(2019\xe2\x80\x932021)</small></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background:">See also</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Coronaviridae" title="Coronaviridae">Coronaviridae</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Novel_coronavirus" title="Novel coronavirus">Novel coronavirus</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/History_of_coronavirus" title="History of coronavirus">History of coronavirus</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r992953826">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbar{display:block;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox-title .navbar{float:left;text-align:left;margin-right:0.5em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Coronavirus" title="Template:Coronavirus"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Coronavirus" title="Template talk:Coronavirus"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Coronavirus&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>A crucial metric in assessing the severity of a disease is the <a href="/wiki/Infection_fatality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infection fatality rate">infection fatality ratio</a> (IFR), which is the cumulative number of deaths attributed to the disease divided by the cumulative number of infected individuals (including asymptomatic and undiagnosed infections) as measured or estimated as of a specific date.<sup id="cite_ref-fjMw6_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fjMw6-80">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WHOest_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHOest-81">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ovoEx_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ovoEx-82">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Epidemiologists frequently refer to this metric as the \'infection fatality rate\' to clarify that it is expressed in percentage points (not as a decimal).<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Other published studies refer to this metric as the \'infection fatality risk\'.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In April 2020, an IFR range of 0.12\xe2\x80\x931.08% was derived from non-peer-reviewed serology surveys, with the upper bound characterised as much more credible and the range indicated as from 3 to 27 times deadlier than influenza (0.04%).<sup id="cite_ref-Fox20200424_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fox20200424-88">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In June 2020, a peer-reviewed analysis of pre-serology data from mainland China yielded an overall IFR of 0.66% (with age-bracketed values ranging from 0.00161% for 0\xe2\x80\x939 years to 0.595% for 50\xe2\x80\x9359 years to 7.8% for <u>&gt;</u> 80 years).<sup id="cite_ref-:11_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:11-89">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In July 2020, the US CDC adopted the IFR as a "more directly measurable parameter for disease severity for COVID-19" and computed an overall \'best estimate\' for planning purposes for the U.S. of 0.65%.<sup id="cite_ref-GYY9Q_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GYY9Q-90">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-g3sm3_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g3sm3-91">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable">\n<caption><span class="nowrap">CDC Planning Scenario IFR Range</span>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>Age group</th>\n<th>IFR\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>0\xe2\x80\x9319</td>\n<td>0.002%\xe2\x80\x930.01%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>20\xe2\x80\x9349</td>\n<td>0.007%\xe2\x80\x930.03%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>50\xe2\x80\x9369</td>\n<td>0.25%\xe2\x80\x931.0%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>70+</td>\n<td>2.8%\xe2\x80\x939.3%\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>In August 2020, the WHO reported serology testing for three locations in Europe (with some data through 2 June) that showed IFR overall estimates converging at approximately 0.5\xe2\x80\x931%.<sup id="cite_ref-WHOest_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHOest-81">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> A systematic review article in <i><a href="/wiki/The_BMJ" title="The BMJ">The BMJ</a></i> advised that "caution is warranted ... using serological tests for ... epidemiological surveillance" and called for higher quality studies assessing accuracy with reference to a standard of "RT-PCR performed on at least two consecutive specimens, and, when feasible, includ[ing] viral cultures."<sup id="cite_ref-BMJ1_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMJ1-92">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CEMBreBMJ1_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CEMBreBMJ1-93">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> CEBM researchers have called for in-hospital \'case definition\' to record "CT lung findings and associated blood tests"<sup id="cite_ref-k7cLH_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k7cLH-94">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> and for the WHO to produce a "protocol to standardise the use and interpretation of PCR" with continuous re-calibration.<sup id="cite_ref-rXFxn_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rXFxn-95">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In September, the CDC computed an age-bracketed \'best estimate\' for the U.S. of 0.003% for 0\xe2\x80\x9319 years; 0.02% for 20\xe2\x80\x9349 years; 0.5% for 50\xe2\x80\x9369 years; and 5.4% for 70+ years.<sup id="cite_ref-C19Planning_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-C19Planning-96">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;c&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In September 2020, a <i>Bulletin of the World Health Organization</i> article by <a href="/wiki/John_Ioannidis" title="John Ioannidis">John Ioannidis</a> estimated the median global IFR inferred from seroprevalence data at 0.23%<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;d&#93;</a></sup> overall (with rates of 0.09% in areas with low mortality, and 0.57% in areas with high mortality) and 0.05% for people &lt; 70 years (a range of 0.00\xe2\x80\x930.31%), much lower than estimates made earlier in the pandemic.<sup id="cite_ref-:62_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:62-99">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 6 October 2020, <a href="/wiki/Michael_J._Ryan_(doctor)" title="Michael J. Ryan (doctor)">Dr. Mike Ryan</a>, director of the WHO\'s Health Emergencies Programme announced "Our current best estimates tell us that about 10% of the global population may have been infected by this virus."<sup id="cite_ref-28deu_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28deu-100">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Also in October, the <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Evidence-Based_Medicine" title="Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine">Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine</a> (CEBM) reported a \'presumed estimate\' of global IFR at between 0.10% to 0.35%, noting that this will vary between populations due to differences in demographics.<sup id="cite_ref-cebm-global-cf_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cebm-global-cf-101">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> These researchers noted a decrease in IFR in England over time;<sup id="cite_ref-jQBAK_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jQBAK-102">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;e&#93;</a></sup> and, for the UK and Italy (the two European nations worst hit by COVID-19), attribute the rise in daily cases, stability in daily deaths, and shift of cases to a younger population to waning viral circulation, misapplication of testing, and misinterpretation of test results rather than to prevention, treatment, or virus mutation.<sup id="cite_ref-bNzul_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bNzul-104">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In November 2020, a review article in <a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)"><i>Nature</i></a> reported estimates of population-weighted IFRs for a number of countries, excluding deaths in elderly care facilities, and found a median range of 0.24% to 1.49%.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In December 2020, a systematic review and meta-analysis published in the <i><a href="/wiki/European_Journal_of_Epidemiology" title="European Journal of Epidemiology">European Journal of Epidemiology</a></i> estimated that population-weighted IFR was 0.5% to 1% in some countries (France, Netherlands, New Zealand, and Portugal), 1% to 2% in several other countries (Australia, England, Lithuania, and Spain), and about 2.5% in Italy; these estimates included fatalities in elderly care facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-EJE_levinetal_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-106">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> This study also found that most of the differences in IFR across locations reflected corresponding differences in the age composition of the population and the age-specific pattern of infection rates, due to very low IFRs for children and younger adults (e.g., 0.002% at age 10 and 0.01% at age 25) and progressively higher IFRs for older adults (0.4% at age 55, 1.4% at age 65, 4.6% at age 75, and 15% at age 85).<sup id="cite_ref-EJE_levinetal_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-106">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> These results were also highlighted in a December 2020 report issued by the World Health Organization.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span id="Case_fatality_ratio_.28CFR.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Case_fatality_ratio_(CFR)">Case fatality ratio (CFR)</span></h4>\n<p>Another metric in assessing death rate is the <a href="/wiki/Case_fatality_rate" title="Case fatality rate">case fatality ratio</a> (CFR),<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;f&#93;</a></sup> which is deaths attributed to disease divided by individuals diagnosed to-date. This metric can be misleading because of the delay between symptom onset and death and because testing focuses on individuals with symptoms (and particularly on those manifesting more severe symptoms).<sup id="cite_ref-Hauser_2020_79-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hauser_2020-79">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> On 4 August, WHO indicated "at this early stage of the pandemic, most estimates of fatality ratios have been based on cases detected through surveillance and calculated using crude methods, giving rise to widely variable estimates of CFR by country \xe2\x80\x93 from less than 0.1% to over 25%."<sup id="cite_ref-WHOest_81-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHOest-81">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Disease">Disease</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Signs_and_symptoms">Signs and symptoms</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID-19" title="Symptoms of COVID-19">Symptoms of COVID-19</a></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r952607947">.mw-parser-output .excerpt .selflink{font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .excerpt-indicator{border-left:3px solid #c8ccd1;margin:1em 0;padding-left:1em}</style><div class="excerpt">\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg/260px-Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg/390px-Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg/520px-Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1972" data-file-height="1001" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Signs_and_symptoms" title="Signs and symptoms">Symptoms</a> of COVID-19</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID-19" title="Symptoms of COVID-19">Symptoms of COVID-19</a> are variable, ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC2020Sym_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC2020Sym-109">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Grant_et_al_2020_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Grant_et_al_2020-110">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> Common symptoms include <a href="/wiki/Headache" title="Headache">headache</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anosmia" title="Anosmia">loss of smell</a><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ageusia" title="Ageusia">taste</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nasal_Obstruction" class="mw-redirect" title="Nasal Obstruction">nasal congestion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhinorrhea" title="Rhinorrhea">runny nose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cough" title="Cough">cough</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muscle_pain" class="mw-redirect" title="Muscle pain">muscle pain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sore_throat" title="Sore throat">sore throat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fever" title="Fever">fever</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Breathing_difficulties" class="mw-redirect" title="Breathing difficulties">breathing difficulties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC-115">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> People with the same infection may have different symptoms, and their symptoms may change over time. Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, sputum, shortness of breath, and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with muscle and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC-115">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> In people without prior ear, nose, and throat disorders, <a href="/wiki/Hypogeusia" title="Hypogeusia">loss of taste</a> combined with <a href="/wiki/Hyposmia" title="Hyposmia">loss of smell</a> is associated with <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32483687_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32483687-116">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Most people (81%) develop mild to moderate symptoms (up to mild <a href="/wiki/Pneumonia" title="Pneumonia">pneumonia</a>), while 14% develop severe symptoms (<a href="/wiki/Dyspnea" class="mw-redirect" title="Dyspnea">dyspnea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hypoxia_(medical)" title="Hypoxia (medical)">hypoxia</a>, or more than 50% lung involvement on imaging) and 5% of patients suffer critical symptoms (<a href="/wiki/Respiratory_failure" title="Respiratory failure">respiratory failure</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shock_(circulatory)" title="Shock (circulatory)">shock</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Organ_dysfunction" title="Organ dysfunction">multiorgan dysfunction</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC_Interim_Guidance_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC_Interim_Guidance-117">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> At least a third of the people who are infected with the virus do not develop noticeable symptoms at any point in time.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic-121">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> These <a href="/wiki/Asymptomatic" title="Asymptomatic">asymptomatic</a> carriers tend not to get tested and can spread the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic-121">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_:2_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_:2-124">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Other infected people will develop symptoms later, called "pre-symptomatic", or have very mild symptoms and can also spread the virus.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_:2_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_:2-124">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>As is common with infections, there is <a href="/wiki/Incubation_period" title="Incubation period">a delay</a> between the moment a person first becomes infected and the appearance of the first symptoms. The <a href="/wiki/Median" title="Median">median</a> delay for COVID-19 is four to five days.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974-125">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> Most symptomatic people experience symptoms within two to seven days after exposure, and almost all will experience at least one symptom within 12 days.<sup id="cite_ref-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974-125">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\nMost people recover from the acute phase of the disease. However, some people continue to experience a range of effects for months after recovery\xe2\x80\x94named <a href="/wiki/Long_COVID" title="Long COVID">long COVID</a>\xe2\x80\x94and damage to organs has been observed. Multi-year studies are underway to further investigate the long-term effects of the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transmission">Transmission</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19" title="Transmission of COVID-19">Transmission of COVID-19</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sneeze.JPG" class="image"><img alt="A man coughing, with droplets dispersing widely into the surrounding air" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Sneeze.JPG/220px-Sneeze.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Sneeze.JPG/330px-Sneeze.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Sneeze.JPG/440px-Sneeze.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4240" data-file-height="2836" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sneeze.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The main route of transmission of COVID-19 is <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_droplet" title="Respiratory droplet">respiratory droplets</a> expelled from the mouth and nose when a person sneezes, coughs, or speaks.</div></div></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><div id="mwe_player_0" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:250px;" videopayload="&lt;div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot;
