data-height=&quot;1080&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;1224680&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.120p.vp9.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;VP9 120P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;120p.vp9.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;214&quot; data-height=&quot;120&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;124984&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.160p.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Low bandwidth WebM (160P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;WebM 160P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;160p.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;284&quot; data-height=&quot;160&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;151904&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.180p.vp9.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;VP9 180P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;180p.vp9.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;320&quot; data-height=&quot;180&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;136880&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.240p.vp9.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Small VP9 (240P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;VP9 240P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;240p.vp9.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;426&quot; data-height=&quot;240&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;148968&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.240p.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Small WebM (240P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;WebM 240P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;240p.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;426&quot; data-height=&quot;240&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;175320&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.360p.vp9.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;VP9 (360P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;VP9 360P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;360p.vp9.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;640&quot; data-height=&quot;360&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;178496&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.360p.webm&quot; type=&quot;video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;WebM (360P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;WebM 360P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;360p.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;640&quot; data-height=&quot;360&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;256528&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"><img alt="File:Safe Spaces - how to reduce virus transmission indoors - 9hP41EaypD4.webm" style="width:250px;height:141px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm/250px-seek%3D402-Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm.jpg" /><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b5/Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Safe_Spaces_-_how_to_reduce_virus_transmission_indoors_-_9hP41EaypD4.webm" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Video explainer on reducing airborne transmission of COVID-19 indoors</div></div></div>\n<p>The virus is transmitted mainly through the respiratory route after an infected person coughs, sneezes, sings, talks, or breathes. A new infection occurs when virus-containing particles exhaled by an infected person, either <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_droplet" title="Respiratory droplet">respiratory droplets</a> or <a href="/wiki/Aerosol" title="Aerosol">aerosols</a>, get into the mouth, nose, or eyes of other people who are in close contact with the infected person.<sup id="cite_ref-Transmission_of_COVID-19_ecdc_transmission_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_ecdc_transmission-128">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> During human-to-human transmission, an average 1000 infectious <a href="/wiki/SARS-CoV-2" class="mw-redirect" title="SARS-CoV-2">SARS-CoV-2</a> virions are thought to initiate a new infection.\n</p><p>The closer people interact, and the longer they interact, the more likely they are to transmit COVID-19. Closer distances can involve larger droplets (which fall to the ground) and aerosols, whereas longer distances only involve aerosols. Larger droplets can also turn into aerosols (known as <a href="/wiki/Droplet_nucleus" title="Droplet nucleus">droplet nuclei</a>) through evaporation. The relative importance of the larger droplets and the aerosols is not clear as of November 2020; however, the virus is not known to spread between rooms over long distances such as through air ducts. <a href="/wiki/Airborne_transmission" title="Airborne transmission">Airborne transmission</a> is able to particularly occur indoors, in high risk locations such as restaurants, choirs, gyms, nightclubs, offices, and religious venues, often when they are crowded or less ventilated. It also occurs in healthcare settings, often when <a href="/wiki/Aerosol-generating_procedure" title="Aerosol-generating procedure">aerosol-generating medical procedures</a> are performed on COVID-19 patients.\n</p>\nThe number of people generally infected by one infected person varies; as of September 2020 it was estimated that one infected person will, on average, infect between two and three other people. This is more infectious than <a href="/wiki/Influenza" title="Influenza">influenza</a>, but less so than <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a>. It often spreads in <a href="/wiki/Disease_cluster" title="Disease cluster">clusters</a>, where infections can be traced back to an index case or geographical location. There is a major role of "<a href="/wiki/Superspreader" class="mw-redirect" title="Superspreader">super-spreading events</a>", where many people are infected by one person. A person who is infected can transmit the virus to others up to two days before they themselves show symptoms, and even if symptoms never appear.<sup id="cite_ref-Transmission_of_COVID-19_ecdc_transmission_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_ecdc_transmission-128">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> People remain infectious in moderate cases for 7\xe2\x80\x9312 days, and up to two weeks in severe cases.  In October 2020, medical scientists reported evidence of reinfection in one patient.</div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cause">Cause</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2">Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg/220px-Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg/330px-Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg/440px-Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="393" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Illustration of SARS-CoV-2 <a href="/wiki/Virion" class="mw-redirect" title="Virion">virion</a></div></div></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\n<p>SARS\xe2\x80\x91CoV\xe2\x80\x912 belongs to the broad family of viruses known as <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus" title="Coronavirus">coronaviruses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2_Fox2020_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2_Fox2020-129">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> It is a <a href="/wiki/Positive-sense_single-stranded_RNA_virus" class="mw-redirect" title="Positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus">positive-sense single-stranded RNA</a> (+ssRNA) virus, with a single linear RNA segment. Other coronaviruses are capable of causing illnesses ranging from the <a href="/wiki/Common_cold" title="Common cold">common cold</a> to more severe diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome" title="Middle East respiratory syndrome">Middle East respiratory syndrome</a> (MERS, fatality rate ~34%). It is the seventh known coronavirus to infect people, after <a href="/wiki/Human_coronavirus_229E" title="Human coronavirus 229E">229E</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_coronavirus_NL63" title="Human coronavirus NL63">NL63</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_coronavirus_OC43" title="Human coronavirus OC43">OC43</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_coronavirus_HKU1" title="Human coronavirus HKU1">HKU1</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome-related_coronavirus" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus">MERS-CoV</a>, and the original <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus">SARS-CoV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2_NEJM-Novel_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2_NEJM-Novel-130">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\nOn 11 February 2020, the <a href="/wiki/International_Committee_on_Taxonomy_of_Viruses" title="International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses">International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses</a> announced that according to existing rules that compute hierarchical relationships among coronaviruses based on five <a href="/wiki/Conserved_sequence" title="Conserved sequence">conserved sequences</a> of nucleic acids, the differences between what was then called 2019-nCoV and the virus from the 2003 SARS outbreak were insufficient to make them separate <a href="/wiki/Viral_species" class="mw-redirect" title="Viral species">viral species</a>. Therefore, they identified 2019-nCoV as a virus of <i><a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome%E2%80%93related_coronavirus" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome\xe2\x80\x93related coronavirus">Severe acute respiratory syndrome\xe2\x80\x93related coronavirus</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diagnosis">Diagnosis</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19#Diagnosis" title="COVID-19">COVID-19 \xc2\xa7&#160;Diagnosis</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_testing" title="COVID-19 testing">COVID-19 testing</a></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\nThe standard methods of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 are <a href="/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test" title="Nucleic acid test">nucleic acid tests</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_pmid32621814_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_pmid32621814-132">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_20200130cdc_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_20200130cdc-133">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_WHO_InterimGuidance_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_WHO_InterimGuidance-134">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited."<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_2k0iS_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_2k0iS-135">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup> The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a <a href="/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab" title="Nasopharyngeal swab">nasopharyngeal swab</a>; however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_CDC2020Testing_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_CDC2020Testing-136">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_20200129cdc_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_20200129cdc-137">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup> Results are generally available within hours.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_pmid32621814_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_pmid32621814-132">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\nChest CT scans may be helpful to diagnose COVID-19 in individuals with a high clinical suspicion of infection but are not recommended for routine screening.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_:0_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_:0-139">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_acr.org_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_acr.org-140">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> Bilateral multilobar <a href="/wiki/Ground-glass_opacity" title="Ground-glass opacity">ground-glass opacities</a> with a peripheral, asymmetric, and posterior distribution are common in early infection.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_:0_139-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_:0-139">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> Subpleural dominance, <a href="/wiki/Crazy_paving_(medicine)" title="Crazy paving (medicine)">crazy paving</a> (lobular septal thickening with variable alveolar filling), and <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_consolidation" title="Pulmonary consolidation">consolidation</a> may appear as the disease progresses.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_:0_139-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_:0-139">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> Characteristic imaging features on chest <a href="/wiki/Radiographs" class="mw-redirect" title="Radiographs">radiographs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Computed_tomography" class="mw-redirect" title="Computed tomography">computed tomography</a> (CT) of people who are symptomatic include asymmetric peripheral ground-glass opacities without <a href="/wiki/Pleural_effusion" title="Pleural effusion">pleural effusions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_AJR_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_AJR-143">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prevention">Prevention</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19#Prevention" title="COVID-19">COVID-19 \xc2\xa7&#160;Prevention</a>, <a href="/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic">Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Social_distancing_measures_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic">Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg/220px-04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg/330px-04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg/440px-04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The CDC and WHO advise that masks reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2. <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> President <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> pictured.</div></div></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_(English).pdf" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf/page1-220px-Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="285" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf/page1-330px-Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf/page1-440px-Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_%28English%29.pdf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1275" data-file-height="1650" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Stop_the_Spread_of_Germs_updated_(English).pdf" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Infographic by the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention" title="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC), describing how to stop the spread of germs</div></div></div>\n<p>Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, wearing a mask in public, avoiding crowded places, keeping distance from others, ventilating indoor spaces, managing potential exposure durations,<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> washing hands with soap and water often and for at least twenty seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_CDC042020_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_CDC042020-145">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> Poor hygienic conditions in underdeveloped countries such as the Dominican Republic, where there is also a gender, class, and ethnic gap, complicate the whole process of COVID-19 prevention.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_:18_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_:18-147">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\nThose diagnosed with COVID-19 or who believe they may be infected are advised by the CDC to stay home except to get medical care, call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider, <a href="#Face_masks_and_respiratory_hygiene">wear a face mask</a> before entering the healthcare provider\'s office and when in any room or vehicle with another person, cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue, regularly wash hands with soap and water and avoid sharing personal household items.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_CDC2020IfSick_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_CDC2020IfSick-148">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vaccines">Vaccines</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine" title="COVID-19 vaccine">COVID-19 vaccine</a></div>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_COVID-19_vaccine_development" title="History of COVID-19 vaccine development">History of COVID-19 vaccine development</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines" title="Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines">Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_vaccination_(2020).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg/220px-COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg/330px-COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg/440px-COVID-19_vaccination_%282020%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4937" data-file-height="3136" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:COVID-19_vaccination_(2020).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A doctor at <a href="/wiki/Walter_Reed_National_Military_Medical_Center" title="Walter Reed National Military Medical Center">Walter Reed National Military Medical Center</a> receiving a COVID-19 vaccination</div></div></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\n<p>In Phase III trials, several COVID\xe2\x80\x9119 vaccines have demonstrated <a href="/wiki/Vaccine_efficacy" title="Vaccine efficacy">efficacy</a> as high as 95% in preventing symptomatic COVID\xe2\x80\x9119 infections. As of April&#160;2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19_pandemic&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, 14 vaccines are authorized by at least one national <a href="/wiki/Regulation_of_therapeutic_goods" title="Regulation of therapeutic goods">regulatory authority</a> for public use: two <a href="/wiki/RNA_vaccine" title="RNA vaccine">RNA vaccines</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pfizer%E2%80%93BioNTech_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Pfizer\xe2\x80\x93BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine">Pfizer\xe2\x80\x93BioNTech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Moderna COVID-19 vaccine">Moderna</a>), five conventional <a href="/wiki/Inactivated_vaccine" title="Inactivated vaccine">inactivated vaccines</a> (<a href="/wiki/BBIBP-CorV" title="BBIBP-CorV">BBIBP-CorV</a>, <a href="/wiki/CoronaVac" title="CoronaVac">CoronaVac</a>, <a href="/wiki/BBV152" title="BBV152">Covaxin</a>, <a href="/wiki/WIBP-CorV" title="WIBP-CorV">WIBP-CorV</a> and <a href="/wiki/CoviVac" title="CoviVac">CoviVac</a>), five <a href="/wiki/Viral_vector_vaccine" title="Viral vector vaccine">viral vector vaccines</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sputnik_Light" title="Sputnik Light">Sputnik Light</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_V_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccine">Sputnik V</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Oxford\xe2\x80\x93AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine">Oxford\xe2\x80\x93AstraZeneca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Convidecia" title="Convidecia">Convidecia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Johnson &amp; Johnson COVID-19 vaccine">Johnson &amp; Johnson</a>), and two <a href="/wiki/Subunit_vaccine" title="Subunit vaccine">protein subunit vaccines</a> (<a href="/wiki/EpiVacCorona" title="EpiVacCorona">EpiVacCorona</a> and <a href="/wiki/ZF2001" title="ZF2001">RBD-Dimer</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_vaccine_london_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_london-150">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (May 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> In total, as of March&#160;2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19_pandemic&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, 308 vaccine candidates are in various stages of development, with 73 in <a href="/wiki/Clinical_research" title="Clinical research">clinical research</a>, including 24 in <a href="/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_I" title="Phases of clinical research">Phase<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I trials</a>, 33 in <a href="/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_II" title="Phases of clinical research">Phase<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>I\xe2\x80\x93II trials</a>, and 16 in <a href="/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_III" title="Phases of clinical research">Phase<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span>III development</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_vaccine_london_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_london-150">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\nMany countries have implemented phased distribution plans that prioritize those at highest risk of complications, such as the elderly, and those at high risk of exposure and transmission, such as healthcare workers.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_vaccine_Beaumont_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Beaumont-151">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Plotkin" title="Stanley Plotkin">Stanley Plotkin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neal_Halsey" title="Neal Halsey">Neal Halsey</a> wrote an article published by Oxford <a href="/wiki/Clinical_Infectious_Diseases" title="Clinical Infectious Diseases">Clinical Infectious Diseases</a> that urged single dose interim use in order to extend vaccination to as many people as possible until vaccine availability improved.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> Several other articles and media provided evidence for delaying second doses in the same line of reasoning.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<p>On 21 December 2020, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> approved the <a href="/wiki/Pfizer%E2%80%93BioNTech_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Pfizer\xe2\x80\x93BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine">Pfizer BioNTech vaccine</a>. Vaccinations began to be administered on 27 December 2020. The <a href="/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Moderna COVID-19 vaccine">Moderna vaccine</a> was authorized on 6 January 2021 and the <a href="/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Oxford\xe2\x80\x93AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine">AstraZeneca vaccine</a> was authorized on 29 January 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>\nOn 4 February 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services <a href="/wiki/Alex_Azar" title="Alex Azar">Alex Azar</a> published a notice of declaration under the <a href="/wiki/Public_Readiness_and_Emergency_Preparedness_Act" title="Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness Act">Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness Act</a> for medical countermeasures against COVID-19, covering "any vaccine, used to treat, diagnose, cure, prevent, or mitigate COVID-19, or the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 or a virus mutating therefrom", and stating that the declaration precludes "liability claims alleging negligence by a manufacturer in creating a vaccine, or negligence by a health care provider in prescribing the wrong dose, absent willful misconduct".<sup id="cite_ref-mXTUz_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mXTUz-157">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> The declaration is effective in the United States through 1 October 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> On 8 December it was reported that the AstraZeneca vaccine is about 70% effective, according to a study.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Treatment">Treatment</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19" title="Treatment and management of COVID-19">Treatment and management of COVID-19</a></div><p>There is no specific, effective treatment or cure for <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" class="mw-redirect" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">coronavirus disease 2019</a> (COVID-19), the disease caused by the <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2">SARS-CoV-2</a> virus.<sup id="cite_ref-BMJLivingReview_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-160">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AutoDW-63_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AutoDW-63-161">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> Thus, the cornerstone of <b>management of COVID-19</b> is <a href="/wiki/Supportive_care" class="mw-redirect" title="Supportive care">supportive care</a>, which includes treatment to <a href="/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment" title="Symptomatic treatment">relieve symptoms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fluid_replacement" title="Fluid replacement">fluid therapy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxygen_support" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxygen support">oxygen support</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prone_positioning" class="mw-redirect" title="Prone positioning">prone positioning</a> as needed, and medications or devices to support other affected vital organs.<sup id="cite_ref-NatureDale_Fisher_&amp;_David_Heymann_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NatureDale_Fisher_&amp;_David_Heymann-162">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KuiFang2020_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KuiFang2020-163">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wang_Du_Zhu_Cao_2020_p._164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wang_Du_Zhu_Cao_2020_p.-164">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_(50119127303).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg/220px-Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg/330px-Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg/440px-Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5180" data-file-height="3466" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_(50119127303).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A critically ill patient receiving invasive ventilation in the intensive care unit of the <a href="/wiki/Heart_Institute,_University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Heart Institute, University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo">Heart Institute, University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo</a>. Due to a shortage of mechanical ventilators, a <a href="/wiki/Resuscitator" title="Resuscitator">bridge ventilator</a> is being used to automatically actuate a <a href="/wiki/Bag_valve_mask" title="Bag valve mask">bag valve mask</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>Most cases of COVID-19 are mild. In these, supportive care includes medication such as <a href="/wiki/Paracetamol" title="Paracetamol">paracetamol</a> or <a href="/wiki/NSAID" class="mw-redirect" title="NSAID">NSAIDs</a> to relieve symptoms (fever,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> body aches, cough), proper intake of fluids, rest, and <a href="/wiki/Obligate_nasal_breathing" title="Obligate nasal breathing">nasal breathing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AutoDW-63_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AutoDW-63-161">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Good personal hygiene and a <a href="/wiki/Healthy_diet" title="Healthy diet">healthy diet</a> are also recommended.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend that those who suspect they are carrying the virus isolate themselves at home and wear a face mask.<sup id="cite_ref-CDC2020IfSick_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDC2020IfSick-170">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>People with more severe cases may need treatment in hospital. In those with low oxygen levels, use of the <a href="/wiki/Glucocorticoid" title="Glucocorticoid">glucocorticoid</a> <a href="/wiki/Dexamethasone" title="Dexamethasone">dexamethasone</a> is strongly recommended, as it can reduce the risk of death.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:02_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-172">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-173">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Noninvasive_ventilation" class="mw-redirect" title="Noninvasive ventilation">Noninvasive ventilation</a> and, ultimately, admission to an <a href="/wiki/Intensive_care_unit" title="Intensive care unit">intensive care unit</a> for <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation" title="Mechanical ventilation">mechanical ventilation</a> may be required to support breathing.<sup id="cite_ref-NIHGuidelines2020_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-174">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation" title="Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation">Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation</a> (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure, but its benefits are still under consideration.<sup id="cite_ref-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p._175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-175">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Henry_2020_p._176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henry_2020_p.-176">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Several <a href="/wiki/Clinical_research" title="Clinical research">experimental treatments</a> are being actively studied in <a href="/wiki/Clinical_trial" title="Clinical trial">clinical trials</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BMJLivingReview_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-160">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> Others were thought to be promising early in the pandemic, such as <a href="/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine" title="Hydroxychloroquine">hydroxychloroquine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lopinavir/ritonavir" title="Lopinavir/ritonavir">lopinavir/ritonavir</a>, but later research found them to be ineffective or even harmful.<sup id="cite_ref-BMJLivingReview_160-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-160">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-177">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-178">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> Despite ongoing research, there is still not enough high-quality evidence to recommend so-called early treatment.<sup id="cite_ref-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-177">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-178">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, in the United States, two <a href="/wiki/Monoclonal_antibody" title="Monoclonal antibody">monoclonal antibody</a>-based therapies are available for early use in cases thought to be at high risk of progression to severe disease.<sup id="cite_ref-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement_178-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-178">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> The antiviral <a href="/wiki/Remdesivir" title="Remdesivir">remdesivir</a> is available in the U.S., Canada, Australia, and several other countries, with varying restrictions; however, it is not recommended for people needing mechanical ventilation, and is discouraged altogether by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO),<sup id="cite_ref-Hsu_p=m4457_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hsu_p=m4457-179">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> due to limited evidence of its efficacy.<sup id="cite_ref-BMJLivingReview_160-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-160">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Variants">Variants</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Variants_of_SARS-CoV-2" title="Variants of SARS-CoV-2">Variants of SARS-CoV-2</a></div>\n<p>Several variants of SARS-CoV-2 have emerged that are spreading globally. The most currently prevalent, all of which share the D614G mutation, are:<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Lineage_B.1.1.7" title="Lineage B.1.1.7"><i>B.1.1.7</i></a>, first detected in the UK, which has spread to over 70 countries</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Lineage_P.1" title="Lineage P.1"><i>P.1</i></a>, first detected in Brazil, which has spread to more than 4 countries</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Lineage_B.1.351" title="Lineage B.1.351"><i>B.1.351</i></a>, first detected in South Africa, which has spread to over 30 countries</li></ul>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prognosis">Prognosis</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19#Prognosis" title="COVID-19">COVID-19 \xc2\xa7&#160;Prognosis</a></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r952607947"/><div class="excerpt">\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg" class="image"><img alt="The severity of diagnosed cases in China" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg/220px-Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg/330px-Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg/440px-Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="482" data-file-height="362" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Severity-of-coronavirus-cases-in-China-1.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The severity of diagnosed COVID-19 cases in China<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\nThe severity of COVID-19 varies. The disease may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the <a href="/wiki/Common_cold" title="Common cold">common cold</a>. In 3\xe2\x80\x934% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalization.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_pmid33087398_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_pmid33087398-183">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover. Among those who have died, the time from symptom onset to death has ranged from two to eight weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_WHOReport24Feb2020_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_WHOReport24Feb2020-184">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> The Italian <a href="/wiki/Istituto_Superiore_di_Sanit%C3%A0" title="Istituto Superiore di Sanit\xc3\xa0">Istituto Superiore di Sanit\xc3\xa0</a> reported that the median time between the onset of symptoms and death was twelve days, with seven being hospitalised. However, people transferred to an ICU had a median time of ten days between hospitalisation and death.<sup id="cite_ref-COVID-19_ISSCharacteristics_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COVID-19_ISSCharacteristics-185">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> Prolonged prothrombin time and elevated C-reactive protein levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID-19 and with a transfer to ICU.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup></div></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Mitigation">Mitigation</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_health_mitigation_of_COVID-19" title="Public health mitigation of COVID-19">Public health mitigation of COVID-19</a></div><p>Speed and scale are key to mitigation, due to the fat-tailed nature of pandemic risk and the exponential growth of COVID-19 infections.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> For mitigation to be effective, (a) chains of transmission must be broken as quickly as possible through screening and containment, (b) health care must be available to provide for the needs of those infected, and (c) contingencies must be in place to allow for effective rollout of (a) and (b).\n</p><h3><span id="Screening.2C_containment_and_mitigation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Screening,_containment_and_mitigation">Screening, containment and mitigation</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:20200410_Flatten_the_curve,_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_(English).gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif/330px-20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif" decoding="async" width="330" height="186" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif/495px-20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif/660px-20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="675" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:20200410_Flatten_the_curve,_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_(English).gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Goals of mitigation include delaying and reducing peak burden on healthcare (<i><a href="/wiki/Flattening_the_curve" title="Flattening the curve">flattening the curve</a></i>) and lessening overall cases and health impact.<sup id="cite_ref-Lancet2020Flatten_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-189">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RnW59_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RnW59-190">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> Moreover, progressively greater increases in healthcare capacity (<i><a href="/wiki/Raising_the_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Raising the line">raising the line</a></i>) such as by increasing bed count, personnel, and equipment, help to meet increased demand.<sup id="cite_ref-Vox_20200407_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vox_20200407-191">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif/330px-20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif" decoding="async" width="330" height="186" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif/495px-20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif/660px-20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="675" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:20200409_Pandemic_resurgence_-_effect_of_inadequate_mitigation.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mitigation attempts that are inadequate in strictness or duration\xe2\x80\x94such as premature relaxation of distancing rules or stay-at-home orders\xe2\x80\x94can allow a resurgence after the initial surge and mitigation.<sup id="cite_ref-Lancet2020Flatten_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-189">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wiles_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wiles-192">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Strategies in the control of an outbreak are screening, containment (or suppression), and mitigation. Screening is done with a device such as a <a href="/wiki/Thermometer" title="Thermometer">thermometer</a> to detect the elevated body temperature associated with fevers caused by the infection.<sup id="cite_ref-f4SpW_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f4SpW-193">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> Containment is undertaken in the early stages of the outbreak and aims to trace and isolate those infected as well as introduce other measures to stop the disease from spreading. When it is no longer possible to contain the disease, efforts then move to the mitigation stage: measures are taken to slow the spread and mitigate its effects on the healthcare system and society. A combination of both containment and mitigation measures may be undertaken at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-NY0JD_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY0JD-194">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> Suppression requires more extreme measures so as to reverse the pandemic by reducing the basic reproduction number to less than 1.<sup id="cite_ref-ImpCollege16mar2020_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ImpCollege16mar2020-195">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Part of managing an infectious disease outbreak is trying to delay and decrease the epidemic peak, known as flattening the epidemic curve.<sup id="cite_ref-Lancet2020Flatten_189-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-189">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> This decreases the risk of health services being overwhelmed and provides more time for vaccines and treatments to be developed.<sup id="cite_ref-Lancet2020Flatten_189-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-189">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> Non-pharmaceutical interventions that may manage the outbreak include personal preventive measures such as hand hygiene, wearing face masks, and self-quarantine; community measures aimed at physical distancing such as closing schools and cancelling mass gathering events; community engagement to encourage acceptance and participation in such interventions; as well as environmental measures such surface cleaning.<sup id="cite_ref-community_mitigation_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-community_mitigation-196">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> Some measures, particularly those that focus on cleaning surfaces rather than preventing airborne transmission, have been criticized as <a href="/wiki/Hygiene_theatre" class="mw-redirect" title="Hygiene theatre">hygiene theatre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hygiene_theatre_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hygiene_theatre-197">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>More drastic actions aimed at containing the outbreak were taken in China once the severity of the outbreak became apparent, such as quarantining entire cities and imposing strict travel bans.<sup id="cite_ref-RwmYm_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RwmYm-198">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> Other countries also adopted a variety of measures aimed at limiting the spread of the virus. South Korea introduced mass screening and localised quarantines and issued alerts on the movements of infected individuals. Singapore provided financial support for those infected who quarantined themselves and imposed large fines for those who failed to do so. Taiwan increased face mask production and penalised the hoarding of medical supplies.<sup id="cite_ref-shZdf_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shZdf-199">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Simulations for Great Britain and the United States show that mitigation (slowing but not stopping epidemic spread) and suppression (reversing epidemic growth) have major challenges. Optimal mitigation policies might reduce peak healthcare demand by two-thirds and deaths by half, but still result in hundreds of thousands of deaths and overwhelmed health systems. Suppression can be preferred but needs to be maintained for as long as the virus is circulating in the human population (or until a vaccine becomes available), as transmission otherwise quickly rebounds when measures are relaxed. Long-term intervention to suppress the pandemic has considerable social and economic costs.<sup id="cite_ref-ImpCollege16mar2020_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ImpCollege16mar2020-195">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Contact_tracing">Contact tracing</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Use_and_development_of_software_for_COVID-19_pandemic_mitigation" title="Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation">Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_health_mitigation_of_COVID-19#Information_technology" title="Public health mitigation of COVID-19">Public health mitigation of COVID-19 \xc2\xa7&#160;Information technology</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><div id="mwe_player_2" class="PopUpMediaTransform" codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;VP9 (360P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;VP9 360P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;360p.vp9.webm&quot; data-width=&quot;640&quot; data-height=&quot;360&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;715120&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"><img alt="File:COVID-19 Airport Contact Tracing.webm"
